title: Echoes: The Best of Pink Floyd
reviewText: IF you love pink Floyd then this hits package is probably not needed.  after all you already have their cd's anyways. However it does have a track that is not available anywhere else. So for that reason you may want it.  that song is 'when the tigers broke free'  , tiger tanks killed roger waters  father during ww2 , and this song is about that. It was recorded for the wall ,  and was in the movie but not the cd version.  So if you want that song then you need this release.  If you want a great bunch of pink Floyd songs that are from 1967-83 and don't want to buy their full cds , then you will like this release as well.  The sound is remastered and that is a good thing as well. The songs styles are psych rock to prog rock and it does feature some real classic songs on here like 'money' and such.  If you love prog rock or psych rock then this is a good one for you . If you are collecting pink Floyd then this is also a good one for you as you will want the tiger song.  It is a good overview of the band , on that regard you may want it too.

recommend_top_items: ['Led Zeppelin II', 'Led Zeppelin 1', 'NaN', 'Then Play on', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Bare Trees', 'NaN', 'Hysteria', '461 Ocean Boulevard']
reviewText: UA did not tamper with the tracks when they released this one.  And they had the cool George Mariin instrumentals on here as well.  SO this one is identical to what buyers got back then. unlike the other u.s. albums which use the british mixes. this one always used the british mixes.  So this is the truest , other than 'the beatles hey jude' to what the u.s. albums were.  IN fact th us albums had far inferior remixes to the british ones. BUt that is a moot point here because this IS the same as the u.s. release. same mixes and all.  this is a like a mini lp and a limited edition. It's the only one I bought so far and it's worth it for beatles collectors.

recommend_top_items: ['Led Zeppelin II', 'Led Zeppelin 1', 'NaN', 'Then Play on', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Bare Trees', 'NaN', 'Hysteria', '461 Ocean Boulevard']
title: Shades of Deep Purple
reviewText: In 1968 there was no hard rock, there was psych rock and bands did covers of all kinds of music making them their own.  Deep purple flew out of the gate with a top ten hit 'hush' , which made them stars. Although they wouldn't become true hard rockers until 1970.  They were in line here with the harder sounding bands of the time.  and this re-issue has some great bonus songs on it.  These guys even at the start had a huge amount of experience coming from several bands and session work, making this a very well played disc! These guys were on the fringe of prog rock in skills but chose to go hard in two years. after they went fully orchestrated. which is why the hall of fame won't let them in? really? one of rocks greatest bands! Anyways this music from the late sixties , a mix of styles but all rock.  The next two would be very similar to this one and use the same vocalist.  but this is worth having because it takes you back to the late sixties with a very good band. It has protometal to psych to pop rock here and it's all well done.

recommend_top_items: ['Led Zeppelin II', 'Led Zeppelin 1', 'NaN', 'Then Play on', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Bare Trees', 'NaN', 'Hysteria', '461 Ocean Boulevard']
title: Street Survivors
reviewText: The deluxe edition is worth your money.  This one has the original criterean versions. And they are inferior to the released version of this one. However they could have left on 'Georgia peaches'  as a  ninth track for sure.  This also has five live tracks as well.  And two versions of 'sweet little missy' . This release was a masterpiece of southern rock and it still stands that way today.  It's heatbreaking that such good artists met such terrible fates , even billy powell is now dead.  Still this is music made from the soul and it's  a band that was at the peak of their game.  If you are going to get this , then of course you want the deluxe version. However the alternative versions of the hit release will be a less polished experience for you.  Those that complain about bonus tracks can stick to the other releases of this one.  which has five bonus tracks instead of a second disc. But completest  people will want this one.

recommend_top_items: ['Led Zeppelin II', 'Led Zeppelin 1', 'NaN', 'Then Play on', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Bare Trees', 'NaN', 'Hysteria', '461 Ocean Boulevard']
title: After Bathing at Baxter's
reviewText: Surrealistic pillow , is a masterpiece of great song writing and playing.  It had a folky acid rock feel to it. THis one was straight acid rock basically and that means a lot of spacey songs. It's looser and less tight. Which is ok for a band to do, but thankfully they got much tighter with their next release as the record buying public found this one lacking in many ways.  I like it, but then I like acid rock,  but even I prefer well crafted tight discs with some meandering songs, Instead of lots of meandering songs!  That being said, this was  a master group and they knew how to do a acid rock disc. I enjoy this one , but casual fans should stick to other releases which are all tighter in format probably.

recommend_top_items: ['Led Zeppelin II', 'Led Zeppelin 1', 'NaN', 'Then Play on', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Bare Trees', 'NaN', 'Hysteria', '461 Ocean Boulevard']
title: Perfect Strangers
reviewText: Deep purple ,version 2 was torn apart in the early 70's at the height of their power and sales.  With this hugely popular release they stormed back in full power.  This one was as if they had never left. WIth songs like perfect stranger and other radio played songs , fans could only hope that this was to last.  It didn't , but at least we have this great cd to remember this reunion again.  There isn't a weak song on here and we don't see any of the funk influence of deep purple circa 1974-76.  Not that those releases were bad it's just that this is what dp does best : make excellent hard rock.  Ian Gilliam is at the top of form here and so is the rest of the band. The late jon lord's keyboards flow into each song. It's all great here , in true dp style.  Of course Ritchie blackmore is laying down great guitar work too , among the other purples. Deep purple a truly  original band shines here.  Why can't the hall of fame see the greatness of this music? it is insane! put them in the hall. and rip jon lord.

title: Anthology 2
reviewText: This one is much like first. We get a few unreleased songs and lots of alternated takes and such.  Which is why this stuff is for beatle lovers mostly.  but it also shows how great they were that people would love this music enough to want to have different versions of the same old songs.  And many of us do , as this was a bestseller. And of course you got their latest single at the time. real love. which of course was a hit.  This is a band that they will listen to as long as people are around to hear music probably , so iff you want to delve deeper into the beatles music then this is for you. and the shound is very good of course.

title: Double Platinum
reviewText: This was  a strange release that was done to show fans that the band wasn't breaking up. As they had put out the solo releases that year. SO they remixed a bunch of kiss klassics and had them record a new version of 'strutter' .  The mixes are interesting , but this being the case, these aren't  the versions that were on the kiss discs of years earlier.  It sold well enough , and fans at the time were glad to have different versions of the bands songs.  The original versions sound better for sure, but these are good versions.  There isn't a bad song on here because kiss didn't have any bad songs at this  point. IMO.  The cover shown here is the german one for some reason and the lightening strike ss's are not allowed there. The rest of the world has the normal kiss ss's  on it.  This is a good one for a casual listener as it does have versions ot their hits on it. But these aren't the mixes they may have heard on the radio.  Completest 's  will want this , and fans back in the seventies helped to make this a platinum seller on it's own right.  the sound is remastered and sadly there are no bonus tracks.  mercury , never seems to do that. which is a shame.

title: Led Zeppelin III
reviewText: When I first heard this  , I was perplexed. There were a few great hard rock songs on here. But there was also folk rock done in  electric style. But it holds up very well as a masterful disc of good music. It's led zeppelin and that is a good thing , but hard rock fans who don't have the tolerance for folk music or psych rock may not be so happy with this one. Just listen to it more than once and you will begin to get the feel of what they were trying to do here. The remastering is excellent as well.

title: Magical Mystery Tour
reviewText: regardless of where these songs were released first. The mmt is a fantastic group of songs.  There isn't a bad song on here and it's a fun bunch of songs.  Of course there's hits on here but even the non hits speak of a group firing on all cylinders and having fun.  The drugs problems weren't yet there to almost destroy them, and other issues.  This really captures the change in pop music , it was really expanding in 1967 and these guys songs were among the best out there.  A really good package for sure.  Any true beatle fan would rate this group of songs among their favorite most likely.  So take a tour into pop perfection with the beatles. the new version sounds much better than the older cd version as well.

title: Schemer-Dreamer
reviewText: I have all of Kansas's catalog so I had t grab this one. I also had it on record back in the day.  It has some cool songs on it. It's similar to Kansas but it's more straight rock and roll to be honest.  This was a young jumping Steve Walsh and he is still great , I saw him and Kansas live in pueblo, Colorado,  June 14 2014 , and he's still got the chops. He didn't jump like he used to though.  Still This has some powerful songs on it,  like 'get too far' and others. And 'Schemer dreamer'  , Steve went for a rocking release and he pulled It off. At the time , he would leave Kansas which was not a good thing to do at all.  He did return to them, and they did manage to put out two very good releases before his return. But Kansas was at it's peak in 1980 still and his departure hurt them for sure.  this one however should delight Kansas fans who like songs like 'got to rock on' off "audio visions' and such.  the cd quality is excellent too.

title: Skynyrd's First: The Complete Muscle Shoals Album
reviewText: Most of this was released as 'first and last'  and all of it was very early recordings of the band as they learn the craft of recording.  This is not the bands best of course.  And casual fans will not find a polished jewel here. Instead this is collector material for the fans.  If you are a fan you should enjoy hearing this stuff.  If you want a more polished era of their music then this isn't for you. This is similar to lets say 'wicked lester' which was pre kiss , where a band is just starting out.  I love ls though , so I had to get this and it's worth your money if you enjoy this band  Just don't expect it to be on the level of what came later.

title: Nuthin' Fancy
reviewText: Ok, when you are GREAT BAND,  like this one or led zeppelin or such,  you can't make fantastic releases every time.  This makes fans say they are losing it. However this is a very good release from a great band. Great music would come from them again of course and there are several great songs on here.  "Saturday night special' , is one of them.  All the others are very good though.  So a weaker ls release is still filled with a lot of good songs and a few great ones. The boys at this point were out of control as well that party lifestyle was already taking it's toll.  Ed king was still around for this one too.  So casual fans will won't to go with their greater releases but to be sure this hasn't a bad song on it. So fans like me are more than happy, but like all fans we want stronger discs on the whole as well..  I can say that this is weaker than their first two for sure.  But the first one is a masterpiece , and this is not. Still you won't be sorry if you like country rock or just rock with this one.

title: Kiss - Rock the Nation Live
reviewText: Kiss is and will be forever one of the greatest live shows ever. It's because they are kiss ,  and that means a persona of music in a sense. This dvd features great kiss songs but the editing is hard and fast. Which is much like u2 live 360.  I am not a big fan of that type of live concert film but in spite of that this is still worth owning for the good tunes on here.  the kissology sets are much better as they don't edit things in that way. But his one still will get you going. The footage is from the 00's so it's very clear as well.

recommend_top_items: ['Led Zeppelin II', 'Led Zeppelin 1', 'NaN', 'Then Play on', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Bare Trees', 'NaN', 'Hysteria', '461 Ocean Boulevard']
reviewText: This has some fantastic songs on it.  'the elephant man' is the best song on here. There's a alternative version of 'all hells breaking loose' with kiss. And most of the songs have decent enough sound , a few of the demos are not so great soundwise ,but very clear sounding.  demos are often done on simple recordings machines. There are snippits of interviews as well. I would recommend this one to any kiss fan.  And  it's hard to believe that this nice and talented man has been now dead for 23  years.  (cancer) .  But then it's sad to lose anyone at any age. Some of these songs should have been done by kiss for sure.  The shandi demo is not with kiss I believe. But it was his audition tape for the band.  This is not a regular completed cd of course , (it's demos and outtakes)  if you want that you will be disappointed , but if you want a piece of kiss history and a remembrance of a fine man and talent musician. then you will have that here.  rip eric.

title: Rock N Roll
reviewText: This is by any standard this is  J.l.'s weakest solo release. It's a tribute disc really and on that level it's as good as any tribute cd.  These are interesting versions of older rock.  From twenty to more years old in 1975 that is.  This is the one completests would want in their collection and casual listeners may be less happy with.  The songs are done the way lennon wanted them to sound and it is a hit and miss affair for many people. I can listen to the whole thing and enjoy every song though. SO I like this one. I like all  lennon's stuff though, except the experimental stuff from the sixties.. So if you want a greater effort don't look here but if you want a interesting tribute cd , then you may enjoy this one. the remaster sounds pretty good too.

title: All Meat No Filler: Best of Fat Boys
reviewText: Rap was all about fun when it was first out, Not like the limited music of today or even more worthless gangsta rap, The fat boys understood melody and even non rap fans could enjoy their sense of humor and the music they sampled was funky,  Old rap was in hindsight a lot of fun when it was done by a group like this one. There isn't a bad song on here. I can't say that about ANY of swill that passes for rap today.  I am not a huge rap fan in the least but groups like this were there to put a smile on your face.  These guys even did a song with the beach boys!  I wish we had more like them and LESS like the slop of today.  The fat boys laid down some good grooves and it's sad that their type of rap is gone.

title: The Beatles The Capitol Albums Vol. 1
reviewText: The capital versions were always pretty bad to begin with , as compared to the uk versions, so you get the us versions in all their badness here. They sound like they did I guess.  I would say that if you want these , in a remastered and excellent way , you should buy the stereo boxset. This is both stereo and mono. the u.s. mono mixes though. And if you want the  uk mono mixes you have to grab the mono boxset , which is out of print. I have it. Still this boxset will make you realize that the overdone reverb and such wasn't needed. Completists may want this but the rest of the public should get the stereo boxset instead.  The new u.s albums boxset , does not feature the mixes in this boxset though. Except for 'hard days night' which is the same.  so if you want a boxset that has the bad u.s. mixes done in the states , to complete your collection. Then get this.  It's not really remastered though.

title: With the Beatles [Vinyl]
reviewText: The beatles were at this time making superior rock and beat music that was very much of it's era. However they were able to not only cover other artists very well , but to release their own songs , songs that were very much  pop rockers or rockers of the time.  These songs give you feel for the time too. Just like a good 4 seasons record would Rock was about short songs and such and danceable beats. That's what you get here  , to expect more is insane , 1962-63 isn't even similar to 1965 as far as music was concerned! .  That's how fast things changed. But this is good stuff .  It's hard to imagine that only five years later this would be seen as something quaint. But it's still worth owning as it's fun and part of that era of good pop and rock songs that a band of the era would try to do as well as these guys!. the sound here is of course improved. I like the stereo sound much better than the mono sound even though it was recorded in mono.  I have the mono box as well. Even so , take a trip back to  simple era in pop rock music and the songs are still worth hearing today.

title: Spiral
reviewText: This new remastered CD issue sounds MUCH better than any previous version I've ever heard. It's a good buy, even if you already own the old LP or a previous CD edition.And this is one of Vangelis' best albums ever. It's also a good start, in case you don't already know this musician.The music is hard to describe. You can check it on Youtube or other websites like this.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Eternal Idol
reviewText: I absolutely love this album, but I compare it to albums by Bon Jovi and other hard rock bands. This is not heavy metal at all.It's a great hard rock album, though. My old LP was in horrible conditions and this CD sounds great! A full booklet, plus a second disc with an alternative version of the album with a different singer. The liner notes explain the whole story. Anyway, you can listen to both versions and decide later which one you like best. I like both.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Heaven & Hell
reviewText: I wish they wouldn't meddle with the original covers of the CDs, but at least the original cover is inside the digipak, with complete liner notes. The CD sounds superb. Best mastering ever.It seems they wanted to keep the original "feel" of the LP, so they didn't split the songs in different tracks. They just kept a single track with all of side A and another one with all of side B, which is OK, since I usually play the whole thing anyway, but... I don't know. There is a considerable pause between the actual songs and they could have made a track number change on those spots. Not sure why all CD versions of the album were made this way. This one is no exception.This is my favorite Vangelis album, but it's also a rather unusual/different one. If you're new to Vangelis, maybe you should start with "Spiral" instead.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Tilt
reviewText: The cover is beautifully unintelligible. The album is mostly like that too. There is a peaceful feeling, but something different. Like you're plunging slowly into a maze in a dark nightmare. You travel and you're not alone. Scott Walker is with you. No, he doesn't guide you. He's just as lost as you are. You go through it together. Until you realize his nightmare was your nightmare too. Strangely, I sometimes fall asleep listening to this CD and I actually have good dreams.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Tabula Rasa
reviewText: I guess everybody's favorite Einstürzende Neubauten album is probably "Haus der Lüge". This is their next album, which isn't all strange or pop or anything harsh. But there's a bit of all styles Neubauten have ever tried in a single album. I'd say it's a nice way to get to know what Neubauten is about, even if you might decide later that another of their albums is your favorite.The CD booklet is very interesting -- I think it was the first digipak I ever bought and no digipaks were as well elaborated as this one. I now bought the cassette edition from Amazon and its insert was slightly different, but just as nice.This album first came out accompanying several EPs with outtakes. I wish they had just made one long album, or maybe one double album with the best versions instead. The EPs are forgettable now, as their best material can be found in "Strategies Against Architecture III".  This album, however, is still a must have, whether you're a fan or someone getting to know the band.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Wild Mood Swings
reviewText: The only bad song on the album is "Gone". No idea how that single even sold at all. The other tracks are all incredibly wonderful!BUT... while "wish" was recorded incredibly low, this is incredibly LOUD.  The sound is very, very distorted because of this. :-(  And there is no other version available for this album.It's incredibly how The Cure have wonderful songs in very poor CD versions. I daresay only cassettes or LPs from them should be bought and, to make things worse, this album is only available in this lousy CD version. Quite a disaster. :-(Mind you: some of their two-disc reissues have very good masters, even if the track selection for the bonuses is something odd at times.

title: Return of the Mother
reviewText: This is one of Nina Hagen's best works ever.  It received limited print, long depleted, no idea why. If you can still find a copy around, do get it. This is strong old Nina, punk-like, rebellious, strong sounding, great voice. But better than the new nonsense she's recording now.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Best of
reviewText: The sound quality may not be "wonderful", but it's much better than other collections I've seen around. Some of the classic albums are now available in new remastered editions with pristine sound quality.Most tracks here are from "Spiral", "Heaven and hell" and "Albedo 0.39".  If you're looking for a new better sounding CD issue of those tracks, perhaps you'd be better served with the new remastered editions of those three albums.If you'll getting to know this artist and are just looking for a single-CD collection with his best tracks to listen to and get to know him better, this cheap CD will probably do the trick for you. I still play it a lot, even though I do now own those three CDs I mentioned above.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Wish
reviewText: The album itself is absolutely wonderful!  Apart from "Wendy time", all other 11 tracks are superb.But the CD was very poorly mastered. The cassette version actually sounds much better.And there are too many wonderful songs from the era that were left-out. Extended mixes of some of those songs are very rare items these days.  The "lost wishes" EP-cassette is wonderful and incredibly rare. And the CD was mastered at a very low volume, with very little treble and just sounds week.  Considering how good this album is, this is tragic.A two-disc remastered version is long overdue now. The band made great reissues of previous albums. Why not this one?

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Secret Dreams & Forbidden Fire
reviewText: I got this old cassette here at Amazon.  Why the CD is missing one track, I have no idea. My old LP is missing two tracks, but I can guess why: running time limitations.  Yet, the CD is still short and all ten tracks would have fit. All ten tracks are absolutely wonderful and this album is, by far, the best Bonnie Tyler has ever released. No idea why it was so ill-regarded and why it's so unknown. It should get a full CD re-issue, remastered, with liner notes, lyrics and all ten tracks. I hope that will be done someday. Meanwhile, get whatever version you can get of it. It is clearly her masterpiece, ravishing, as the first track, from start to finish. I strongly recommend this album. And, oddly enough, yes, I recommend the cassette version, since it's the only one to contain all ten tracks.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Defenders of the Faith
reviewText: In my opinion, rather than adding tracks to them, they should have re-released "Screaming for vengeance" and "Defenders of the Faith" with no bonus tracks on a single disc. Yes, they would fit. The new mastering is superb. The cover is messed with, breaking the old front-and-back picture with this grey frame which, in my opinion, should not be there at all.  But those are two wonderful albums that sound a bit alike and these new remastered editions do sound great. The booklets are complete with lyrics, photos and liner notes.The bonus tracks on these new remastered editions are all from the wrong era. They should have made a separate album with all those non-album tracks instead.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
reviewText: You can check here what the original LPs were like. Mini LP covers, each disc exactly as the old European LP was like. Strangely, some of the covers show the track listing from the US edition while the CD contains the European edition instead. The real track listing can be found in the booklet, which doesn't bring very good liner notes, but is acceptable.The CDs do sound good.No live recordings were included, not even "Abba Live!", which was an official live album.But there is an extra CD with non-album songs from singles.So, in the end, nothing is repeated. You can let all discs play continuously and you won't grow tired of it.The discs are well mastered and sound just fine.But I still wish they had included all lyrics in the booklet. And covers with real matching information. And the long version of "Summer night city", rather than the original single. And better liner notes.From the collections I know, though, this is the best one you'll get. At least "The name of the game" is in its full version here -- most collections go for the single version instead, which is missing the best part of that song.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Metal Works 1973 - 1993
reviewText: As the liner notes indicate, somebody's favorite track may not be here, but a wide variety of the band's produce is found in this long-playing 2-CD collection. About two and a half hours of music. Excellent mastering, nice liner notes, beautiful cover.And... some of my favorite tracks aren't there and some tracks, in my opinion, shouldn't be there. For instance:  only two songs from "Turbo" are really good, and only two songs from Turbo are there.  But the good songs are "Turbo" and "Out in the cold"; this collection contains instead "Turbo" and... "Wild nights, hot and crazy days", which is.... well... just.... OK.It's also missing "Heavy Duty/Defenders of the Faith", but I suppose that one was never a big hit, even though it is my favorite Judas Priest song.Nothing from their first two albums is here simply because Columbia Records and Judas Priest have no rights over the old Gull recordings. But at least "Victim of Changes" is present in a very good somewhat live recording from "Unleashed in the east", which isn't bad at all.The best tracks from most of their classic albums are here. This is something you can just let play through a long trip or a party without worrying about which tracks to select. Two very full CDs. If you already have all their albums, there's nothing new here. But if you're new to the band, this is a great way to start. If you're looking for a best-of, this is the best collection you'll find. The only thing better than this is buying the actual original albums.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Sheer Heart Attack
reviewText: This has always been my favorite Queen album of all. The CD re-issue I had was not bad at all, but didn't include the insert with the large pictures the original LP had. I checked out some old editions and they looked beautiful. I decided to give this new vinyl re-issue a try.The record sounds superb and has a beautiful label. The insert is huge and absolutely wonderful! This is *THE* edition to buy! You won't regret it.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Various Failures
reviewText: So "white light from the mouth of infinity" and "love of life" are now out of print.Well, not all is lost.Many singles were released during that era and many tracks were wonderful, but hard to find.Here you will find the best tracks from those two albums plus most of those singles' b-sides.The best song from that era, in my opinion, is "The Picture of Mary Anne", which was the b-side to the 12" version of one of their singles, I can't remember which one now. I only knew it from bootlegs. And it's here!Two very long CDs. This is as good as it gets. It's actually a great start for new listeners, too.In addition to this, I recommend "Children of god" and "burning life".

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Haus der Lüge
reviewText: Haus der Lüge is one of this band's best efforts ever and quite an accessible album, if you can get past the first track. The words are important, but the insert includes translations into English, in case you are not fluent in German.Despite the strange introduction in the album, it's a rather "mild" album throughout the rest. I'd recommend people should start with Tabula Rasa instead, to see both soft and heavy songs. But, sure, this is a wonderful album and not a bad beginning.  It's a lot different from their previous albums and one of the richest forms of sound-art I've ever heard.I'd say this album is a must-have. The CD version includes some nice bonuses.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
reviewText: This two-CD set is absolutely beautiful, but quite disturbing. Even the cover is beautiful, yet disturbing. The music is not heavy-sounding. It's rather soft, but it evokes the darker side of our minds and grows developing a deeper and more exasperated feeling. It's rather hard to describe. You have to listen to it. Warning: you won't like it the first time. But you'll love it the 5th time you play it.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Love of Life
reviewText: The two "bunnies" albums are Swans greatest feats. Why they have gone out of print is beyond me. They were accessible enough for pop audiences and different enough for those getting into no-wave music.  You should start with "white light from the mouth of infinity" and then "love of life". But be careful: the booklet is rather shocking. I absolutely adore it!You will only find expensive used copies now, unfortunately. Michael Gira, why not reissue these two wonderful pearls??

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Heavy Metal: Music From The Motion Picture
reviewText: If you haven't watched the 1981 "Heavy Metal" animation, don't even bother.I love that animation and I love most of the songs in this collection.It contains 16 tracks, 14 of which I absolutely love!!! I've played old copies of this so many times I've actually wrecked one of my tapes. I currently own a well-preserved LP copy, a cassette I still play in my car (so I drive a very old car with a tape player -- so what?) and a CD which would be unplayable after so many listens if it were an LP or a tape.The cassette and LP have nothing extra, nor do they sound better than the CD edition. I have them for nostalgia reasons only. But do watch the movie and get the CD soundtrack. You won't regret it.And... no, if you're looking for "a heavy metal album", this is not it. Most tracks are NOT heavy metal songs. If you're looking for a heavy metal compilation, you should be the old "Metal Killer Kollections" volumes 1, 2 and 3 instead. The old LPs or tapes. The CD versions were cut short -- veeeery short.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Rocka Rolla
reviewText: This album was out of print, then available with a new cover that did it no justice, horribly remastered buy Koch. Now, Repertoire has finally restored it to its full glory! Well... almost.  The track "Rocka Rolla" is in the cut version made for the US LP. The original UK LP contained a longer version of it, which I only possess now in an old British vinyl edition of "Hero, Hero" (which has never received a good CD version so far, and was even worse on cassette -- "Hero, Hero" is only good in British LP edition, unfortunately).So all those tracks could be found in "Hero, Hero", true. But now I have a good CD version with their original versions. And "Diamonds and rust" was added as an extra. The original cover is back on it. It's still a great buy.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Soundtracks for Blind
reviewText: Two very long CDs. I like to put either disc in my stereo and let it play to sleep. The music is soothing, yet disturbing. Like my dreams. And I like it. Let it play, close your eyes and let your mind go.The music is somewhat disturbing, but not unnerving. It's avant-garde, true, but not all that weird. If you want something heavy to pound your head to, however, this is not it.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: Children of God / World of Skin
reviewText: "Children of god" is not for the weak of heart. The album sounds dark, somber, strong, pounding, scary. It's brilliant. The new cover is absolute garbage, unfortunately, but at least the album now contains an extra track, previously available only as a single B-side.This edition comes with a bonus disc: a collection of Swans' side project "Skin". Somehow, I don't think those two discs belong together. But the booklet does include all lyrics.  "Children of god" is represented with a cross while "skin" is represented with a snake. Two sides of a coin, I suppose. But Skin is actually the "light" material and less important.This is the only edition currently available of "Children of god". The recording is at times different from the old album (I still have an old LP edition of it), but it does sound slightly better. I only wish they hadn't messed with the cover. "World of skin" could have been a separate release.

recommend_top_items: ['Seven & The Ragged Tiger', 'Hell Bent for Leather', 'NaN', 'Turbo', 'NaN', 'Momentary Lapse of Reason', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Metal Church', 'Unmasked']
title: This Woman's Work
reviewText: There is only one thing that's wrong with this collection:  it's out of print!if you can find a used one in good conditions, just get it.Her first six albums in their original versions + 2 CDs containing non-album tracks, all in an absolutely gorgeous hard box holding the 8 jewel cases + an extra booklet with more liner notes. You won't regret it.

reviewText: 3rd album from British band who play crunchy-hard, diverse guitar rock with somesharp, blistering fretwork.  The songs are clever & muscular, with some surprising twists & turnsthat always churn within the rock ‘n’ roll arena.  There’s a developed sense of gritty blues rockthat integrates smoothly into melody-structured near-pop songcraft.  The band covers a lot ofground here and, although you’re never sure what the next song will sound like, it’s always acohesive, ear-pleasing piece of rock ‘n’ roll music.  Tough to describe, easy to listen to.  Recalls avariety of bands:  The Kills, Black Rebel Motorcycle Club, the Duke Spirit, White Stripes, TangoAlpha Tango, Led Zeppelin, the Clash, Free Energy, Palma Violets.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: On their 5th release, Arctic Monkeys have made an album with soul.  Not a soul album, but onethat reaches deep into the creative spirit-core of moodiness and is allowed to flow outwardnaturally.  The songs here all have a smooth spark of laid-back and rhythmic, melancholicmuscle—whether it’s a retro-ballad with a trip-hop bass thump, a funky blues guitar riff number,a dip into T. Rex boogie or a distinctly British rock ‘n’ roll rumble.  There is a cohesive, connectedfeel throughout that just rings warm, organic & right.  Sometimes recalls the Style Council, FranzFerdinand, Bombay Bicycle Club, Manic Street Preachers, Bloc Party, the Beatles, Kasabian.This is the sound of a mature band making music rather than trying to sell records.  Pretty cool.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: California’s Fu Manchu are back with their 11th studio album—a maximum stoner rock ‘n’ roll love punch, right in the face!  The guitars are cranked to the max and played L-O-U-D with an all-out bluesy/metal vehemence.  The buzz and roar of energy is intense, tight and totally addictive.  Every time they play a song, there is no doubt in your mind that they mean it.  Scott Hill doesn’t really sing, but speaks with passion over the terse, fluid growl of guitars.  Drums & bass punch & rumble in all the right places with the instinct of a band that knows each other’s moves & moods.  The lead riffs are sharp and punchy; they stop & start on a dime and fly off guitarist Bob Balch’s fingers like lightning bolts from the Gods while the rhythm guitar bangs out chunky chords that sound like 1000 punk rockers beating on a mountainside.  Members have played in Kyuss, Skid Row, the Obsessed, the Heroine Sheiks, Social Distortion. Recalls bands like Kyuss, Goatsnake, Queens of the Stone Age, Fireball Ministry, Greenleaf, Gonga, Unida, Truckfighters, Feedtime.  Fu Manchu always bring the rock.  It’s what they do.  Nobody does it better.  When “Gigantoid” kicks your ass, you’ll bend over and ask for more.  It’s that good!  Recommended for all rockers.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 5th album from Chicago band who play beautiful and captivating, harmony-laden guitar pop withclassic, timeless melody lines.  These are unpretentious, pure, bare-your-soul songs withfolk/roots chamber pop sentimentalism permeating the retro-sweet melodies.  It’s totally uncooland utterly magnificent music.  Includes members of Wilco, Uncle Tupelo, Swan Dive.  Recalls anumber of artists:  the Byrds, Teenage Fan Club, the Zombies, Beach Boys, Wooden Birds,Shack, Buffalo Killers, the Beatles, Nada Surf, Simon & Garfunkel, etc.  “Fifth” is the sort ofalbum that you want to curl up on the couch with; hot chocolate in your hand, head-nodding grinon your face.  Nice.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 4th album from Philadelphia band—Imagine if a Bob Dylan/Nikki Sudden clone, with his voice intop-tuned form, decided to sing for a contemporary indie rock band.  And this band favoredforward-thinking, expansive, smooth-flowing arrangements for driving down a gently shimmeringdesert highway.  The War On Drugs is that and more.  Adam Granduciel’s voice is in its mostexpressive form.  The songs that flow by your window ring with the poignant, easygoing warmthof an old friend, radiating a haunted, echoing resonance of comfort and openness.  A gentle airof Americana expressionism takes on an epic motorik rhythm and the gas pedal sings like anangel on vacation.  Beautiful and accomplished, “Lost in the Dream” is an album to treasure andshare with a friend.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 5th release from Florida band who play complex, accessible metal that combines chunky, old-school power slash chords with psychedelic prog-rock and quick-changing tempos.  Songs tendto be epic & exploratory, with a crunchy fist-in-your-face muscularity that co-exists withprogressive melody structures and vocal harmonies.  This blend of boundary-crossing rock alsomixes technical rhythms and varied time signatures in a melody-driven mish-mash of math/jazzsplatter metal and some spectacular, bombastic lead riffs.  Some similarities to Baroness, KingCrimson, Muse, Uncle Acid & the Deadbeats, Opeth, Prong, early Queen.  For all of its peculiarchaos, the overall album comes off as a cohesive, well integrated piece of music that’s playedwith an innovative ear for open-minded metal-heads and genre-crossing rockers.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: Yet another album (the 21st?) of short, hook-filled, lo/mid-fi pop gems from the creative & prolific Ohio duo of Robert Pollard and Tobin Sprout.  As usual, it’s unbelievably fun and raw, insightful and immediate, and a joy to listen to.  May their well never run dry.  Shades of Elf Power, Apples In Stereo, Super Furry Animals, the Capstan Shafts, early Who.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: Legendary Ohio rockers return with their 8th album and the first in 15 years—There is a diversityof style here that encompasses hard-edged, evolving bluesy grunge-grunt numbers, some gentlyfrenetic & peculiar mid-tempo rhythmic rockers and a few soulful & soaring, orchestrated balladscharacterized by the raspy emotional intensity of Greg Dulli’s voice.  The band seems to be attheir best when they start from a place of controlled melody and slowly explode as Dulli’s vocalswrap themselves around the coils of your heart.  Members & contributors have played in theTwilight Singers, the Gutter Twins, Chavez, Emeralds, Queens of the Stone Age, the Raconteurs,Squirrel Bait.  Recalls acts like the Mark Lanegan Band, Band of Skulls, Mudhoney, AmericanMusic Club, Soul Asylum.  “Do To the Beast” is a solid album that feels like it could be a slowgrower.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 17th? studio album from legendary New York group led by Michael Gira.  His world is a theatre of conceptual darkness where mood and atmosphere are the key elements of sound.  The 34-minute center track is a reign of haunting terror that moves from gently twisted sound vibrations to all-out wall-shattering noise.  The 8-minute “Oxygen” finds a devastating angular lock-funk groove that escalates to slide guitar mayhem over anguished yelps.  Other moments of soul-searching intensity include:  An apocalyptic marching folk music dirge that builds to a white noise ending.  Slow & dramatic psychedelic blues ballad soundscapery with some creepy found-sound conversations and laughter that elevates in tension.  Disturbed hypnotic chants that emphasize repetition as a conquering tool.  A mantra-like, percussive death-clatter that pursues the P.I.L. area of Eastern rock until it self-immolates.  A Savage Republic style buzz-drone of tribal echoes that finishes with a slow-growing, burning blast of earth-shattering noise-scrapes.  Band members on this epic double album have played with the Heroine Sheiks, Shearwater, Ministry/KMFDM.  Guest artists include members of St. Vincent, Cold Specks, Angels Of Light, Colour Revolt, The Paper Chase, Larsen, Beat Circus, Myopic, Wires On Fire, etc.  Swans pay  a lot of attention to detail, which requires the listener to do the same.  “To Be Kind” is not kind; It’s a deep, swallowing hole that is all about the journey downward.  Michael Gira has a unique artistic intensity and magnitude that will enthrall some and exhaust others.  Know the risk; take the trip if you’re up for it.

reviewText: 2nd release from New York duo featuring Sean Lennon & Charlotte Muhl—trippy & melodic psychedelic indie pop with friendly vocal harmonies and subtle hooks that embed themselves in your happy place.  The songs are captivatingly memorable with excellent production and an impressive creative flow that makes use of some less traditional instruments.  “Midnight Sun” is a light-hearted, eclectic and entertaining pop/rock album with a secret depth of twinkly-eyed meaning that would make father John proud, and is well worth repeated listens.  Recalls, not surprisingly, the Beatles + Robyn Hitchcock and bits of Pink Floyd, Peter Ivers.

reviewText: 12th studio album from these icons of the San Francisco scene, orchestrated by the talented, notoriously eclectic & egocentric Anton Newcombe—epic, lope-along psychedelic indie pop with a big, soothing drone-flow.  The songs have a playful 60s pop flare that’s often augmented with horns, strings and a Middle Eastern folk twist.  Recalls bands such as Asteroid No. 4, Boogarins, Solaram, Velvet Underground, the Beatles, Foxygen.  It’s the laid-back sound of someone who’s traveled to the other side on the wings of an opium-smoke angel—a  mesmerizingly haunting trip.

title: Radio Moscow

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: The 2nd album from this Nashville icon and member of White Stripes, Dead Weather & the Raconteurs has a very warm and natural blues/rock feel.  Though it doesn’t seem particularly retro or dated, there is a deep-running roots element throughout the album that keeps it grounded in history.  Somehow, White manages to make this all sound both contemporary and pure; not “modernized”, mind you—he’s just able to reference the past and still be perfectly right for now, for this moment.  There’s no doubt that the blues is king here (with country & folk near the throne), but it only functions within the castle of White’s songwriting; and, while I’m not sure there are any particular stand-out tracks, “Lazaretto” (the album, not the song, which is my least favorite here) has the feel of something you’ll go back to, and discover something new each time.  Sometimes reminds me of the Black Keys, Jack Oblivian, Billy Childish and a variety of old school American blues players, with a few Led Zeppelin riffs tossed in.  It’s a strong second solo album.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 2nd album from all female Los Angeles band—elegantly celestial, atmospheric indie pop/rockwith a haunting air of dark & delicate electro-dub rhythm over seductive, dreamy voices.  Thesongs feel gentle and fragile, more likely to break than bend, as they wander (a bit aimlessly)through realms both eerie and airy.  Overall, the album has a sort of hypnotic, druggy-angelfeel, but lacks any real reason for me to want to hear it again, and seems destined for the salepile.  Nice, but it just puts me to sleep.  Sometimes recalls School Of Seven Bells, later BlondeRedhead, Beach House, CocoRosie, Memoryhouse.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: Well, it looks like everyone else here so far loves this, so I'll be expecting some "not helpful" votes.  This is what I hear:  fluid & melodic indie pop with a subtly driving, rhythmic feel over a wide array of instrumentation and vocal harmonies.  I do love Steadman's voice; it's complex & fragile, often adding an emotionally winsome quality to the gorgeous, flowing songs.  Obviously, for some people, this rings the right bell.  Here' the thing:  I absolutely loved 2010's "I Had the Blues..."; it was my #1 album of that year! And I thought 2011's "A Different Kind of Fix" was pretty good.  But, for me,  "So Long, See You Tomorrow" has jumped the musical shark.  It's just too much of a safe, over-produced and predictable move.  Reminds me of Snow Patrol, XTC, Pulp, Electric Soft Machine, Peter Gabriel and George Michael.  Yep, that's right, the guy from Wham!  Hoping for something different on the next one.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 3rd album from New Jersey band—fragile, dreamy, echoic indie guitar pop that sparkles like therich, glowing kindle-ember of an eternal, meditative flame.  “Atlas” is a lambent basket ofmelodies to lull the listener into a bliss-state of shivery-warm, relaxing low-key passion.  Thesongs carry a consistent, mellifluous charm that’s more about the overall atmosphere of thealbum than the distinctiveness of each individual melody.  They emanate the kind of soft beautythat could free-flow  through the auditory center of your brain forever on a mesmerizingly infinitejourney.  This is music befitting a glass of fine wine and a knowing, winsome smile with a sigh ofcomfort.  Recalls bands like Felt, Widowspeak, Wild Nothing, Luna, Tranquility, Beach House,Orange Juice.  Gloriously rich and exceptionally pretty songs which might put you to sleep, butyou’ll have happy dreams.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 4th album from Baltimore duo who have softened things up by leaving the rock guitars in the closet.  “Shriek” is made up of soothing & sophisticated indie keyboard rock with complex and compelling melody lines that float through fields of emotion with a buoyantly penetrating beauty.  There is a surface lightness to the album that belies the depth of sincerity and underlying mystery.  The songs have a dreamy, almost soulful, epic pop flow with an attractively eerie hint of danceable darkness.  Members have played in Dungeonesse, Flock of Dimes.  Some similarities to Blonde Redhead, Fear Of Men, Everything But the Girl, the Shins, Cocteau Twins.  The combination of bouncy electronic rhythms and Wasner’s angelic voice creates an overall calming atmosphere for a smooth, tranquil auditory experience, but it lacks the punch of their earlier releases.

Shades of Ten Years After(There’s a cover of “Hear Me Callin’” on the album.), Mountain, Cream, Blue Cheer, BuffaloKillers, James Gang, Savoy Brown.

reviewText: On her 3rd solo album, Chicago artist Angel Olsen is here to unload & entertain, and she’s notshy about it.  Whether in a deceptively gentle acoustic number or a twang-guitar driven rocker,she gathers her emotions in the voice and lays them all over your heart.  Sometimes recallsNeko Case, Lindi Ortega, Jesse Sykes, Scout Niblett, Erika Wennerstrom (Heartless Bastards).This is Americana/folk-tinged indie rock with substance and a surprising power.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 12th album from legendary Athens, Georgia band—Drive-By Truckers are the poets ofcontemporary Southern guitar rock.  I know it sounds unlikely, but this is intelligent “good-old-boy” rock ‘n’ roll.  Patterson Hood & Mike Cooley write lyrics that dig way below the surface ofday-to-day small town existence, with an insightfulness that brings the words to life.  ImagineLynyrd Skynyrd with a degree in creative English literature.  Yeah, and then there’s the music!Tight, anthemic, confident Southern roots rock with guitars that alternately sparkle and rage insuch a smoothly integrated way that the whole song tends to quietly explode with a subtle,muscular power.  Some similarities to Hold Steady, Wilco, Bruce Springsteen, Water Liars, NeilYoung & Crazy Horse, the Band, Johnny Cash, Allman Brothers Band, The Dexateens.  Withinthe genre, and even beyond it, this is as good as it gets.  Drive-By Truckers are a gift to becherished by thoughtful rockers everywhere.  Superb.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: The debut full-length album from this Canadian trio is packed with poignantly flowing Americana- flavored indie pop with beautiful and memorable melodies, and some gorgeous vocal harmonies.Joe Pernice’s (The Pernice Brothers, Scud Mountain Boys) voice resonates with the power ofheartfelt emotion; it’s one of a kind.  Norman Blake’s (Teenage Fanclub) harmonies and pure popsense are stellar.  Mike Belitsky’s (The Sadies) feel for retro-roots rock adds the final touch.  Thesongs have a generally sparse and acoustic instrumental structure that allows the songwriting,the vocals and the melodies themselves to shine through.  Includes a cover of a Sandy Dennysong.  Recalls artists such as the Byrds, the Hollies, Almost Charlie, Robyn Hitchcock, theBeatles, Cardinal, Simon & Garfunkel, the Beach Boys.  This is music with no pretense and notmuch “cool” factor.  It’s warm & organic, pure & comfortable; a soft, old sofa to sink into.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 4th album from Cleveland, Ohio boys—Raw, vehement, post-punk indie hipster rock that attacksthe melody with an intense noise-drone energy.  The songs growl with punch & purpose, rippingthrough the core of the tune to shred it with speed and aggressively distorted ferocity.  This ismusic that seems to cradle a pending explosion, building a sort of quasi-melodic, edge-of-your-seat tension & energy that recalls some 90s alt-rock bands.  (Think Nirvana, Pixies, Fugazi,Husker Du.) I almost like this.  There are definite moments of high energy promise and appealhere (“Now Hear In”, “No Thoughts”, and especially “I’m Not Part of Me”), but it just feels likethere’s too much noise for the sake of noise.  It’s a screamo pop-terror punk roar of insolentdissonance that I probably won't listen to again.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: U.K. legends return with their 12th album and the first in five years—epic, flowing wide-scope rock that soars from the stadium to the sky on wings with strings, big reverberating guitar chords and Ian McCulloch’s lofty vocal presence.  “Meteorites” is heavy on the production (by Youth of Killing Joke fame) and lacks some of the sonic punch found on earlier releases.  In particular, the presence of Will Sergeant’s guitar seems generally more underplayed.  Still, it sounds like an Echo & the Bunnymen album, and that’s a good thing.  Not their best moment, but well worth a listen—if only to revive the thrill of the first time you heard “Oceans”.  Similarities to bands like Chameleons UK, Icicle Works, Teardrop Explodes, The Horrors, Love & Rockets.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 3rd album from Ames, Iowa band of blazing, garagey, blues guitar rock with a psychedelic metaltwist and some totally mind-blowing guitar hero antics.  Sometimes recalls Jimi Hendrix, labelmates Henry’s Funeral Shoe, the Groundhogs, Taste/Rory Gallagher, Ten Years After, etc.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 6th album from consistently impressive New York band—Nobody tells a better story with songthan the Hold Steady.  Their lyrics peel off the layers of personality from small town lifecharacters, unveiling their innermost feelings with an honesty and insight that’s rare in any formof writing.  The power behind the words lies both in the epic emotional nakedness of Craig Finn’svoice and the inspiringly anthemic, passionate rock ‘n’ roll delivery by the band; they often recallother artists like Bruce Springsteen, Drive-By Truckers, Thin Lizzy, Okkervil River, the GaslightAnthem & Titus Andronicus.  The Hold Steady like to rock.  They like to have a good time, andthey like it to mean something, to matter.  “Teeth Dreams” delivers the goods.  The band, whichincludes former members of Lucero & Lifter Puller, is tighter than ever; they sound rejuvenated.They don’t care if you think they’re cool; they just want you to listen, to feel something.  Youknow how sometimes you can just tell that an album is going to get better every time you hear it?This is one of those times.  Brilliant.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 7th release from this Los Angeles band—“Mess” marks a return to the oversized distortion andaggressive confrontation of their earlier work.  This is electronic beat music that’s up-front andin-your-face, demented & demanding dance-floor spazz grooves.  Although the songs have achallenging attitude of experimentation, the adept combination of cohesion and chaos, mixedwith dark tribal elements and a fun/creative flow—plus an increased awareness of core melodylines—gives this “Mess” a new range of accessibility and power.  Reminiscent of bands likeF--- Buttons, Lust For Youth, Aphex Twin, Plastikman, Cabaret Voltaire, Boards Of Canada, Autechre.Yet another surprising cool chapter in the book of Liars.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 3rd album from Scott Hansen out of San Francisco—dreamy-smooth & epic, motorik-tingedsoundscapes with warmly textured layers of lush electronic keyboards and guitars.  Beautiful,relaxing, hypnotic chill music that recalls the Phoenix Foundation, Boards Of Canada, Eat LightsBecome Lights, Ultraista, Ulrich Schnauss.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: 3rd release from Canadian artist & former member of Makeout Videotape—strange and beautiful singer/songwriter pop with a slightly sad & winsome nonchalance.  Like his previous albums, it’s still wrapped in a peculiarly subtle sleaziness, but the songs are a bit more reserved this time; the subconscious darkness nearly gone.  DeMarco’s husky-whisper vocals have a gently disconnected resignation that is charming, hypnotic and easy to embrace.  The odd, brittle-pretty guitar lines carry a twangy tropical island minimalism that adds character and focus to the songs.  Reminiscent of bands like Orange Juice, Beach Fossils, Lou Reed, Wild Nothing.  “Salad Days” is an album of uniquely edgy-soft pop that stays in the comfort zone.

recommend_top_items: ['NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Very Best of Major Lance', 'Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Ju...', 'Plainsong', 'NaN', 'NaN', 'Upsy Daisy Assortment']
reviewText: London band return with their 4th album of E-P-I-C soaring psychedelic rock.  As on 2011’s excellent “Skying”, the songs are packed with sweeping, lush melodies that carry a grandiose reach-for-the-sky feel.  Glorious shoegazey flower-power guitars are woven through 80s style ambient/rhythmic synthesizer waves and fronted by expansive “new romantic” rock star vocals.  Magnificently overblown, majestic and dangerously near pretentious, “Luminous” defies the odds and rises up as a powerfully rich & satisfying musical journey.  Recalls bands like Toy, Teardrop Explodes, Tame Impala, Echo and the Bunnymen, Hookworms, Secret Machines, Modern English, Simple Minds, Spiritualized, Pink Floyd.  It’s an album of luxurious, beautifully elevated psychedelic music seeking to fill the universe.

title: The Division Bell
reviewText: This is truly an amazing work of art from start to finish. Stands neck and neck with the all time greats. The songs are so well crafted and recorded and far better than Momentary Lapse (which wasn't that bad). I am an old school Floyd fan. My favorites include Animals, Dark Side, Wish You Were Here, Obscured By Clouds, The Wall. This is HIGHLY recommended for any fan of Pink Floyd......wow! It still blows my mind that a Pink Floyd fan cannot like this masterpiece of an album!!UPDATE 07/02/14- VINYL REISSUE REVIEW: Absolutely fantastic job...perfectly dead quiet throughout, not even the slightest crackle or pop. A fantastic and damn near perfect job on the mastering, I am not sure how it could possibly be better. Now, please release Animals, Pulse, and all of the Experience versions on vinyl as soon as possible!!!!

recommend_top_items: ['Full Moon Fever', '30 #1 Hits', 'Long After Dark', 'Ultimate Prince', 'Mighty Rearranger', 'Up Escalator', 'Talk Is Cheap', 'Universal Mother', "It's Only Rock 'n' Roll", 'NaN']
title: Live Rust
reviewText: I just listened to this (on vinyl) from front to back on blistering volume. This stands neck and neck with Weld for the best live Neil Young ever. The best versions of Hey Hey My My and Tonight's The Night that you will ever hear. Cortez The Killer is another highlight. Also a great section of acoustic stuff to begin the show. This along with Weld and Rust Never Sleeps are all essential. Track down an lp version if you can!

recommend_top_items: ['Full Moon Fever', '30 #1 Hits', 'Long After Dark', 'Ultimate Prince', 'Mighty Rearranger', 'Up Escalator', 'Talk Is Cheap', 'Universal Mother', "It's Only Rock 'n' Roll", 'NaN']
title: Live at Fillmore 1968
reviewText: Five Star Santana Performance, no doubt about it. I was really happy to find this one. I think I have a slight preference for disc one but they are both great. Very happy with the recording and sound quality. Some excellent guitar work here. I cannot yet rate it against other live Santana as I have not heard them yet but you cannot go wrong with this one.

title: Monkey Island
reviewText: This is an absolute incredible piece of art here. I would rank this very highly as it stacks up against almost any 70's music. The diversity on here is astounding. What a truly amazing band, never to be forgotten. Yes everyone has their Geils favorite but for me this is the measuring stick. How the hell can this only have 28 reviews!!!???

title: Ragged Glory
reviewText: I love everything about this masterpiece. The production is top notch and you can tell that Neil spent some serious time and effort on creating this. It probably does rank in my top five all time although Neil has so many good ones it is tough to pick the favorites. Quick list: 1. Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere 2. On The Beach 3. Zuma 4. Live Rust 5. Ragged Glory 6. Weld 7. Rust Never Sleeps 8. After The Gold Rush 9. Freedom 10. Harvest/Harvest Moon

title: By Numbers
reviewText: This album is tight as hell and definitely one of the greatest released by this incredible band. I put this slightly below Who's Next. It is THAT great! The songs are more basic and straightforward but the musicianship is mindblowing. If you are new to the Who and have not heard this yet I highly recommend it. This kicks ass!!!

recommend_top_items: ['Full Moon Fever', '30 #1 Hits', 'Long After Dark', 'Ultimate Prince', 'Mighty Rearranger', 'Up Escalator', 'Talk Is Cheap', 'Universal Mother', "It's Only Rock 'n' Roll", 'NaN']
title: Aftermath
reviewText: This is a highly overrated album and three stars at best. I also find it comical to see all the reviews claiming you must buy the UK version. Trust me, there is no way two songs can make that much of a difference! I would also say that Paint It Black is the best song on the album so if that is omitted that is a major minus. Now I will not say this is terrible but as with any Stones prior to 1968 there is a major step down from their best work. I own 23 Stones albums and would rank the three Stones eras the following:1. pre 1968- three stars at best, some nice songs in there but not consistent masterpieces, the blues covers are fine but we all know that this band was far superior to be doing blues covers. It does provide good historic perspective though. Not enough driving rock guitar for my tastes.2. The golden era 1968-74: This is clearly the pinnacle of the Stones with an amazing run of albums. Mostly five star material here and even It's Only R & R and Goats Head Soup have many solid tracks3. The disco new Stones era includes Some Girls, Tattoo You, Undercover, Steel Wheels: Highly underrated by many and for me much more enjoyable than the old 60's stuff. Mostly four star material with a few five star gems thrown in.Anyway, if you love 60's music you will most likely love Aftermath. For me personally this one will collect a lot of dust.

recommend_top_items: ['Full Moon Fever', '30 #1 Hits', 'Long After Dark', 'Ultimate Prince', 'Mighty Rearranger', 'Up Escalator', 'Talk Is Cheap', 'Universal Mother', "It's Only Rock 'n' Roll", 'NaN']
reviewText: First off, this review will solely focus on disc three which is the ONLY reason and a very good reason to purchase the Experience Edition of this classic Floyd album. I do not think there has been enough mention on here about how GREAT the third disc is, with versions of the songs that easily could have made it on to the original album. Specifically the Another Brick In The Wall songs are fantastic and in my opinion almost better than the album versions. I also must mention that these are vastly different than the songs, with different lyrics in alot of places. It is amazing to hear these to understand the working process of finalizing the songs on the album. Other songs are clearly still in progress and not the polished masterpieces that they would become. Either way, I think that many people are selling this short as I read in one review it was something you only needed to hear once. BS. Many of these demo versions are fantastic and fresh and I will be listening to them over and over. I may even make a mix and add some of the best demo's to the Wall in different places.To mention the re-master: What about the original sound of this incredible album would even make you think it needs to be re-mastered in any way at all!!?? Of course it doesn't!!! I will probably never even listen to it. I bought this set only for disc three which greatly exceeded by expectations. These "demo's" sound pristine and the word demo really does not even do them justice!Lastly, what a collection of crappy reviews on this site that seem to have been written by ten year olds! We don't care if your CD was crushed in shipping or if it never arrived. Those are simply useless reviews. Also, reviewing the original album is fine but what people really want to know is "how is disc three" and how does the re-master sound (if they care about that). I am finished with my rant for the day!

recommend_top_items: ['Full Moon Fever', '30 #1 Hits', 'Long After Dark', 'Ultimate Prince', 'Mighty Rearranger', 'Up Escalator', 'Talk Is Cheap', 'Universal Mother', "It's Only Rock 'n' Roll", 'NaN']
title: Goats Head Soup
reviewText: Masterpiece...plain and simple. Shockingly underrated. This will keep you well occupied from start to finish with no duds here. 1968-1974 was the pinnacle of the Stones with plenty more incredible music after that period as well! Get this one NOW!!!

title: Ted Nugent
reviewText: If you don't have this in your classic rock- metal collection you are seriously missing out. Some of the finest guitar licks ever layed down by anyone. Stranglehold is one badass rock anthem!! Nuge must haves: this album, Free For All, Amboy Dukes Call Of The Wild and Tooth Fang and Claw, Cat Scratch Fever.

title: Nightmares...And Other Tales From The Vinyl Jungle
reviewText: I may not be able to really give you a "critical review" as I think this band put out all five star masterpieces except for around three albums. This is absolutely one of their strongest works, possibly just a shade below Bloodshot, Monkey Island, or Sanctuary. Amazing from start to finish and not a weak track in the lot.

title: Live at the Fillmore East
reviewText: What is with all these silly three star reviews complaining about the DVD or the paper cd holder. I am reviewing the six songs included on the spectacular CD that I consider one of the very best in my extensive collection. This is incredible and an absolute MUST for any Neil fan. Top form, tight as hell, live and ON FIRE! You can NOT deduct stars because it doesn't have Cinnamon Girl or because it is only 6 songs. Many of Neil's original albums were shorter than this. Anyway, I am done venting. Buy this five star masterpiece immediately!

title: Rainbow Concert
reviewText: I have heard most live Clapton except Crossroads 2 and i rate this very, very high on the list. Probably a step below Dominos live at the Filmore but this is really a fantastic show. I love the raw sound of it. Those who complain about the CD are a confusing bunch. I have the vinyl and this is one of the very rare cases where the CD actually does sound BETTER than the vinyl, no question about it. I do agree that it is disappointing they shortened guitar solos but you also get many more great tunes on the CD which are not included on the lp. What this really deserves is a deluxe release on 2 180 gram vinyls including all of the songs from the show. Until then, this CD remains the best choice. Specifically, it sounds more crisp and not nearly as muddy as the originally vinyl edition.

title: Wish You Were Here
reviewText: It is amazing that these songs from this incredible concert exist in such pristine sound quality. I bought the set simply for the live disc and was not the least bit disappointed. These songs actually vary greatly from their finished studio versions. This probably has the best version of Shine On You Crazy Diamond I have ever heard. The other songs included are early versions of Sheep and Dogs which are both spectacular. Lastly, a great studio version of Have A Cigar which I think beats the original and a solid version of Wish You Were Here as well. They need to release all of these incredible live performances on a vinyl box set!! Please!!! We need more live Floyd on vinyl!!!

title: In the Flesh: Live
reviewText: I have given this a few listens through and have settled on three stars which is too bad because it could have gone down as a four or five star effort. First the positives, I liked the song selection. The inclusion of Dogs was great although it is not a good as the studio version. Set The Controls For The Heart of The Sun is probably my favorite song here and very well executed. The Wall songs sound fantastic except for Mother. The Final Cut song is nice and pretty well done and Shine On You Crazy Diamond is strong. I did not have a huge problem with the fill in guitar players but will say there is only one David Gilmour. The downsides include the "cringe worthy" back up singing on many of the songs. I cannot reach for the skip button fast enough on songs like Mother. In reading the CD booklet notes I was concerned by the idea of giving every musician his own space to add something of their own to the songs. Roger Waters should have simply sang all of the David Gilmour parts, this would have been acceptable. Instead the songs are so transformed, absolutely NOTHING like the originals because a trio of female singers are in place of the many of the Gilmour parts. Other criticisms include having another version of Money and some underwhelming Dark Side songs. In my opinion both Pulse and the highly under-rated Delicate Sound blow this away. The best live Floyd out there is on the Experience versions of Dark Side and Wish You Were Here. I have also heard that The Wall live show Is There Anybody Out There is also incredible. The David Gilmour live in Gdansk is simply stunning and highly recommended. Sadly, I do not see playing this disc that much with so much other incredible live stuff to chose from.
